comments.commentBody:
Thanks for the amazing job that you have done in pulling together these multi-sourced reports on the situation in Haiti - the good, the bad and the ugly.

I am so inspired by the spirit of the Haitian people, the determination of the aid groups to save lives and the ingenuity of reporters in spreading the word by all means possible.

I read in the NYT where the US, France and Brazil will be meeting on Monday in Montreal to discuss the airport situation--landing slots. This is about a week too late, but better late than never.

While I happen to think MSF tend to view their flights as a top priority, even when others maybe landing equally important supplies. There is a coordinator from the relief groups helping to establish priorities for landing slots, the flow of celebs into Port au Prince is very troubling--What on earth are John Edwards and Sean Penn doing there?

The air force has done well to get the airport running as well as it has, but everyone needs to look at working out the kinks in setting priorities for landing slots. Hopefully, the discussions in Montreal will facilitate this end.

Kudos to the French government for showing restraint in the face of a very frustrating situation for everyone. There have been some rough spots, but cooler heads have prevailed.
Martha Coakley could have saved some time in her interview with "The Boston Globe" by simply stating "More people voted for the nude guy."

What a coincidence- Obama takes a stand against Wall Street and the Supreme Court makes a decision that will hurt his reelection or ability to carry out any of his proposals.   The last election showed the power of the people and here we are once again reminded that we should not get too excited about democracy and much less about a president with ideals and trying to make changes.  The Supreme Court did not do their job.  Once again.   They ignore the precedents, the law, the people, democracy.  Too bad they do not think that they are accountable to anyone.  This is an attack to democracy but also a direct attack to our president and what he stands for (what he was voted for).  Let's not get discouraged and let's support any congressional action which may somehow control the damage they have done.
Senator Hutchison has NO experience regarding economic policy and financial management whatsoever.  She would be disaster for our state.

"There's no reason to speculate about my conscience or my motives. :) I deal with both on my blog."

I combed said website; i do see that both you and Tom Delay "Care" about the children (in written word).

I did not see any explanation whatsoever a justification as to why:
The American tax-payer should involuntarily engage in Marxism by its government granting money to people who "have a dream". The GOP has taught us for that we should depend on the private sector for venture capital.

If you claim this is not the general position of your beloved tea-party and your posting here, then you will have identified my original observation: that a glaring conflict between preach and practice seems exist and persist.
Google makes Mobile Hardware? I thought HTC made Nexus One.....
I would include Google under Music Hardware, since the Nexus 1 has a music app standard.
Desktop hardware should probably be on that chart somewhere.  Isn't that how Apple makes most of it's money?

Apple has behaved like a monolopy which is not good for a consumer.
Recently I bought for the first time a Mac product, a 15" MacBook Pro. The hinge for the screen is loose. The "genius" at the Apple store told me that it was normal then proceeded to demonstrate the same loose hinge on another MacBook Pro and ended up with the loose screen swinging open and crashed on to the counter.
The latest Snow Leopard OS occasionally suffers from the run-away problem just as Windows. Safari & Firefox & Google Chrome sometimes take up high CPU usage causing overheating. This is surprising for a UNIX based system.
It is very difficult to get Apple to admit that their high-priced products have design fault.

I do not have an iPhone or Nexus one either. But, I’ve read couple of articles on this ongoing technology war. I’ve come to this conclusion; it’s all coming down to the customers’ preference. Apple has more applications than Nexus One. The iPhone connects easily to iTunes, pictures and music. The search engine for Apple store is more efficient then Android. But, enhancement like QSB makes it a little bit easier. Apple has always controlled the application development on the iPhone; which is not the case for Google Nexus One. Web surfing is obviously much easier on Nexus, it sounds like the person digitally lives in the Internet. What about implementing the use of WIFI to get a cell phone reception? This will come handy if you are in a “dead zone”; which seems the case for AT&T most of the time.
Despite these differences, the factor that matters the most in my opinion; and helps left up the confusion fog is the network coverage. AT&T customers suffer on a daily basis from weak coverage. When I will decide to buy a Smartphone I think I am going to go with Nexus One. I’ve read an article in the Washington Post that Nexus One is coming to Verizon, which is better coverage than AT&T. If they equipped the Nexus One with the cloud computing concept, then problem solved. I will be able to have access to all of the applications, data, and communications on remote servers. I just hope that Verizon network infrastructure will be able to handle such evolution .After all cloud computing makes computing person-centric, rather than device-centric.
I think for Apple you can add a light blue dot in the maps section. They purchased Placebase to be the alternative to using Google maps
So I guess Sidekick, made by Danger, a Microsoft company, is not mobile, or not hardwary enough?
Poor Angels. Now they're down to just 3 centerfielders?

GeneG,

You have again made many unsubstantiated claims.

Ignore away!

Let's get the Italian fashion houses to start making dresses out of Python skins. Pay Naomi Campbell to pose for a Vogue cover in a genuine python-skin bustier.

Then we coax Diane Kruger to attend the Oscar ceremony in a skin-tight python-skin mini-dress.

Then we spread the word east of Suez that eating python meat restores ...vigor...better than pwdered rhinoceros horn.

Then we build a perimeter of restaurants around the Everglades specializing in haut cuisine based on python meat.

-Python Stroganoff
-Python sauteed in white wine and served with a terragon sauce
-Python Parmiagiana
-Chicken-fred Python
-Python fillets topped with sauce from sun-dried tomatoes, garlic, oregano, basil and extra virgin olive oil
-Telingua chili with rice, beans, jalapeno peppers and python
-Python burgers with spicy jack cheese and Dijon mustard, on a sesame seed bun, with extra sweet potato fries

It is devoutly to be hoped that enterprizing local spirits would soon plunder the swamps for the raw materials to meet this newly generated demand. Local unemployment will vanish as facilities are set up to cater to python tourists from all corners of the world.

If standard human greed operates, depend on it that the fast-growing python industry will hook, harpoon, trap, net and shoot these pesky serpents down to numbers too low to count.

At which point, depend on it also, some good-hearted, weak-headed befuddled sentimentalist will demand that these vile intruders be put on the Endangered Species List.

"You'll appreciate this article of mine from the Alaskan oil frontier:
http://www.nytimes.com...
Great article, thanks.

What a mess. I hope this spurs congress to reinstate the taxes that used to pay for superfund cleanups. There is more of this kind of thing out there are we are very very slow to clear it up because the polluters don't pay.

And thanks to all the people who have helped the Clearwater over the years, you've inspired other watersheds with your efforts.

Re:#34

As I understand it, President Eisenhower wasn't too excited about granting statehood to Alaska. Partly, he was afraid it would interfere with military operations. But I he aslo could be described as a conservative conservative. He wanted to keep Alaska as it was. In an effort to protect a portion of it "for future Americans," he set aside the reserve. Twenty years after he did, they were already fighting over it.

My concern is not so much the minimal amount of damage I believe would occur in the area through new technology, but that is is another part of our history that is being eroded away in the name of profit ... or national security if you will.

I agree on gymnasts working on bars, but if they tumble, I hope it is not from the bars.

On to the next puzzle.
How could you not mention Bing Crosby's?

Hey Tanier. What happened? All season long your columns were by far the most entertaining sports writing on the web. Amusing esoteric references coupled with hairpin turns into unexpected humor were the norm. The playoffs have brought bland and incomplete analysis to say the least. Grab some coffee, close the office door and give us something fun after next week's conference championships. Let's keep it rolling into 2010. Miss the old Mike...

Tired, tired, tired. Hyatt Grand Champions Resort and Spa was delightful, low key, multiple pools, comfortable suite with a sunken "livingroom" that you can turn the flat screen towards and enjoy a movie or savor the morning mountain view from the bed. We loved it. Following trends? Yawn. Jonathan Adler? Overrated kitch. You can't build an experience around it.

WEAK! It is clearly an improvement over North Point, which was the most horribly run coffee shop (I've seen better lemonade stands).  Bad call especially since there are also a number of empty storefronts on Caledonia one block away. It's looking like Ghostalito now. I recommend 'Van Bo's Coffees & Paintings' for the space....oh, nevermind, he's probably considered too popular to be 'local' now.
Traditional Chinese culture favors tolerant religions like Buddhism and Taoism that coexist with each other, not "believe my God or go to hell" religions like Christianity and Islam.
